title: Leadership Styles & Situational Leadership
description: Match leadership style to team maturity and task complexity using situational leadership.
objectives: Identify five core leadership styles (transformational, transactional, laissez-faire, autocratic, democratic)
Apply situational leadership by matching style to team maturity
Recognize when to use facilitation vs direction

screens.headline: 3 Teams. 3 Maturity Levels. One Question: Which Leadership Style Fits Each?

dialogue.text: Alex, just pick a leadership style and be consistent. All this switching is confusing.

counterpoint.text: One size fits no one. Match your style to the team's maturity.

screens.learningHook: Three teams, three maturity levels. Learn to apply the right leadership style for each situation.

screens.title: Leadership Style Matching
screens.instructions: Match each team to the appropriate leadership style based on their maturity and needs.

options.text: Autocratic (directive, leader decides)
Democratic (consult, then decide)
Laissez-Faire (hands-off autonomy)
Transformational (empowering vision)

feedback.correct: Strong match! Low experience = need for DIRECTIVE leadership. New hires need clear commands, step-by-step training, close supervision initially.
feedback.incorrect: New hires lack experience and need clear direction. Autocratic (directive) leadership is most appropriate initially.

scenarios.title: Kitchen Brigade (Michelin-level chefs)
description: Motivation: Autonomy, trust, recognition of expertise

options.text: Autocratic (directive control)
Democratic (consult team, leader decides)
Laissez-Faire (hands-off, team decides)
Transactional (rewards/punishment)

feedback.correct: Perfect! High expertise + autonomy readiness = hands-off leadership. Veterans resent micromanagement—they know their craft. Trust them.
feedback.incorrect: Michelin-level chefs with 15+ years don't need supervision—they need autonomy. Laissez-faire fits experts who are self-directed.

options.text: Autocratic (top-down decisions)
Transactional (compliance rewards)
Laissez-Faire (complete autonomy)
Transformational (empowering vision)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Creative work + diverse team = empowering vision. Transformational inspires innovation and encourages idea-sharing.
feedback.incorrect: Creative teams need vision and empowerment, not compliance or top-down control. Transformational leadership fosters innovation.

decisionTree.question: What is the team's experience level?

lowExperience.question: Is it a crisis or urgent?

content.insight: Match style to team maturity, not your personal preference.

insights: Laissez-faire requires HIGH trust and team maturity—only works with experts
Transformational inspires through VISION, not control—builds intrinsic motivation
Transactional is short-term; can't sustain motivation long-term
Situational leadership adapts to CONTEXT, not personality—one size fits no one
commonMisconceptions: Be consistent = use one style everywhere → Consistency = matching style to context
Autocratic is bad leadership → Appropriate for crises and inexperienced teams
Laissez-faire works for everyone → Only for highly skilled, mature teams

correct.text: Thank you for the clear direction. We're new—we need to know exactly what to do.

incorrect.text: We just had a near-miss with food safety because no one was supervising. Laissez-faire doesn't work for beginners.

correct.text: Finally, a leader who trusts us. We've been doing this for 15 years—we don't need babysitting.

incorrect.text: If you want to micromanage, find someone else. We don't work for people who don't respect our craft.

correct.text: You painted a vision and trusted us to create. That's how innovation happens.

incorrect.text: If I'm punished for failed experiments, I'll only pitch safe ideas. That's not innovation.

screens.title: Convince Carlos About Situational Leadership
screens.context: Carlos is frustrated: 'Just pick ONE style and stick with it. Switching is confusing!'

scenario.title: Reframing Consistency
scenario.challenge: Explain why situational leadership IS consistency.

dialogue.text: Just pick ONE leadership style and stick with it!

options.text: Situational leadership IS consistency—I'm consistently matching style to each team's maturity.
I'll try to be more uniform going forward.
PMI says we should use situational leadership.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Reframe Carlos's understanding of consistency.
feedback.incorrect: Don't abandon the principle or be too generic. Explain that matching style to context IS consistency.

dialogue.text: Explain what you mean by matching style to maturity.

options.text: Rookies lack experience—directive prevents safety risks. Veterans have 15+ years—micromanaging insults their skills.
Some teams need more guidance, others less.
It's complicated. I can send you articles.

feedback.correct: Excellent! Specific explanation with concrete reasoning.
feedback.incorrect: Be specific about WHY different maturity levels need different approaches.

dialogue.text: Give me specific examples from OUR restaurant.

options.text: Catering crew gets directive guidance to build competence. Marco's brigade gets autonomy because they're experts.
Different teams have different needs based on experience.
I treat everyone with respect and professionalism.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Concrete Savory examples make the case compelling.
feedback.incorrect: Use specific examples from the restaurant to make your case.

dialogue.text: But what about customers? They see inconsistency!

options.text: Customers don't see my leadership—they see quality results from empowered teams doing their best work.
Customers focus on food quality, not management style.
I'll try to be less visible so customers don't notice.

feedback.correct: Excellent! Focus on outcomes (quality results) that customers actually experience.
feedback.incorrect: Address Carlos's concern directly by explaining what customers actually see.

screens.title: Situational Leadership Mastery
screens.summary: Effective leaders adapt their style to team maturity and task complexity—one size fits no one.
takeaways: Laissez-faire requires high trust and team maturity—only for experts
Transformational inspires through vision and empowerment (not control)
Situational leadership adapts style to context (team maturity + task complexity)
Consistency = consistently ADAPTING to the team, not using one style everywhere

characterClosing.text: I thought 'consistent leadership' meant one style. You showed me it means consistently ADAPTING to the team. That's harder—and better.
